poem:
Ballad of the Crumpleclaw Jam

At click-o'-clock the inkthrum spun,
click-clack about the room;
The traygloom gaped; the sprockets run,
whirr-warn of paper doom.

Mind Crumpleclaw, a trayborn claw,
with grit-grim, grinding tread;
It lurks by Tray Two, primed to gnaw—
shh-snap, the pages shred.

I primed my palms with helphex tips,
clip-clip the cover wide;
A dejam-wand and pinchwise grips,
click, swish, the panels slide.

Out crept Crumpleclaw, spindle-snarl,
from fuser's blistered seam;
With grabby gums and gristle-snarl,
skritch-scratch through toner-gleam.

Raised the feedweaver, unjam-blade,
beside its paper lair;
With rip-rap wring, the snarl was flayed,
zzzap—zzzip! no clog in lair.

We hauled the husk of Crumpleclaw,
hurrah the trayjub tide;
No more the trays will suffer gnaw—
ding-ding! the printlings ride.

At clack-o'-clock the inkthrum purrs,
click-clack, a cheery gleam;
The traygloom grins; the sprocket whirs,
whirr-hum, the pages gleam.

poem:
Song of the Yesterwyrm

Take heed of Yesterwyrm, green sprig,
its Twice-Again is true;
whirr-where the whens go wiggle-wrig,
and cuckoo-clocks go coo.

I primed my Blinkblade, bevel-bright,
and packed my Roundwatch too;
click-clack! my kit of knotted light,
for facing déjà-do.

Through murmur-mirrors, mizzle-moon,
I strode the whenward wood;
shush-shift! the trails looped back too soon,
and Echo-thorners stood.

The Yesterwyrm, with yawny eyes,
came serpentspiral blue;
“again-again!” its gyro-cries—
zim-zam! the night said “boo!”

I whirled the Blinkblade, clatter-crash,
its brightloop bit in two;
whing-whang! a backwards thunder-splash—
the Yesterwyrm I slew.

I tramped to hearth of Now-at-last,
the dusk un-did its dew;
hip-hip hooray, the loops blew past,
and ding-dong! rang in new.

Take heed of Yesterwyrm, green sprig,
yet keep your courage new;
whirr-where the whens may wiggle-wrig,
remember: you came through.

poem:
Metronox in the Music Room

In stavegloom of the music room
the benches bleat and creak;
Heed the Metronox that booms there
tick-tock with iron beak.

Soft cymbla-sighs and stand-shadows
went shh and clack k-chak;
I gripped my rosin'd bowblade firm
for boomble's shadow-sack.

The tutor's tongue went titter-tock,
mind rests and raging runs;
That beat-beast bites the late and slack,
avoid its mettal lungs.

I tiptoed past the tambourshelves,
plink-plonk pianos pealed;
Through raftrum dusk the needle-gnomes
went zing and softly wheeled.

Then thrum-thrum! from the metry dark
a click-clack shadow loomed;
The Metronox, with pendle-spark,
tip-tappity, it boomed.

I raised my bowblade—slash-a-swish—
the time-teeth snapped and snarled;
I cleft its tock with tremor-thrust,
ka-CLANG! the gears ungnarled.

Its pendle-eye went poppish pale,
its tick turned thin as mist;
I drove cadenclaw through its scale,
and hush, the room was kissed.

Back through the stave-arch students swarmed,
hurrah and boom-bah-bright;
We danced a jigglenote and warmed
the drums with thrumful light.

In stavegloom of the music room
now benches beat and speak;
No Metronox nor gloomglut boom,
just pling and playful squeak.

poem:
The Delaydrake of Layover Bay

At Layover Bay, the waitwinds moan,
beware the Delaydrake, stay;
The dockclock ticks in tarry tone,
and gulls go skreek—keep away.

It slinks with laglamp lantern-eyes,
through bleary, brackish spray;
Its queuetooth grin goes click-clack-guise,
it loves to make you stay.

I buckled on my gatepass glaive,
and donned my staysteel gear;
With checkclock charm and travel-shade,
I marched from quay to pier.

I stowed a snackpack, thunk-thunk tight,
and looped a luckline near;
My laglace boots went stomp by light,
thrum-thrum along the pier.

From fogbanks full of blinkbrine bloom,
ka-SPLASH! went Layover Bay;
The Delaydrake hissed doom-by-doom—
its whiskertide beard gray.

I raised my tickblade, timetail keen,
ka-CLANG! it sang to day;
Swish-swash, whirr-thrum, through scaly-sheen—
the delay was cut away.

Back up the quay the cheerchimes boomed,
hurrah for Harborway!
The barrelbacks banged, the porters zoomed,
hip-hey! No need to stay.

At Layover Bay, the waitwinds purr,
no Delaydrake to stay;
The dockclock hums with quickwind whirr—
and travelers waft away.

poem:
Agendagast in the Conference Room

Beware Agendagast, my crew,
in glassy gloom it broods;
Where swivelwinds and staplers stew,
click-clack the coffee-moods.

She raised her laser-pointer blade,
and notepad as her shield;
While brainstorm-benders, markers brayed,
prepared, her purpose sealed.

And huffing came Agendagast,
buzz-buzz, its memos hissed;
It flapped its flannel-folded past,
and PowerPointed mist.

Ping! went the clicker—zap and zing,
the charts cut clean and true;
She slid through silos, slicéd spin,
snip-snap—the 'Gast she slew!

Return we did to boardroom blue,
ker-chink! the keycards sang;
We brewahooed and clapped anew,
hurrah-hurrah, ding-dang.

Beware Agendagast, my crew—
no more its gloom intrudes;
Beware? Nay, toast the table too,
click-clack the coffee-broods.

poem:
Awl and the Skreekle-Maw

Beware the skreek of night-shop gnaw;
When hookwinds nip the jaw,
And awlpoints prickle-poke the dark,
Heed hammer-hush and jaw.

For out there prowls the Skreekle-Maw,
A stitchsnout none yet saw;
It skitter-saws through shadowstock,
With rasping, ribboned craw.

I gripped my awl of prickly-gleam,
Click-clack, a canting clang;
Its point a pinfire needle-spear,
A tip-tap, tangling tang.

Through leather-lanes I lantern-crept,
Swish-whistle, whisker-hiss;
The benches breathed of glue and grain,
Skritch-scratch, the shadows hiss.

Then out sprang Skreekle-Maw—skree-skraw!
Its nailgnash primed to maw;
I raised my awl—thwip-thwok went steel,
And poked it through the maw.

Back home I trod the tanner’s lane,
With tap-tap, tinkling cheer;
We clapped our cups—clink-clonk, hurrah!
Awl-wielder without fear.

Yet still the night-shop skreek may gnaw;
When hookwinds tease the jaw,
So keep your prickle-pointed tool,
And harken, awl and jaw.

poem:
Creepwind Canticle

When glimmergloom goes gloamward low,
and slinkershade goes deep,
Beware the Creeplegrue, my sprout,
it skritch-skritch sifts and creeps.

With whisperwire and knuckle-thread,
the duskling lanes go thin;
It nibbles night with nuzzle-teeth,
click-clack beneath your skin.

Now knot your braveribbon tight,
and prime your pebbled blade;
I'll oil the throttle-lantern’s wick,
tock-tock for night parade.

We’ll tiptoe through the tatter-lanes,
where murk-moss muffles feet;
Yet hush! the Creeplegrue comes near,
thrum-thrum its hunger-beat.

It slouches like a shadow-snake,
with coldling candle-breath;
I sprang a jink-step, swung the gleam,
whack-whee! we waltzed with death.

The Creeplegrue made gnashy-grin,
and spat a sooty spark;
I thrust the pebble-saber sure,
skreek-skreak! and split the dark.

We lugged its duskdrip trophy home,
through twindle-silver rain;
The town untucked its sleepy bells,
ding-dong for brave-ling gain.

We feasted on the fizzing pie,
and twirled the ember-flag;
Old auntie hummed a hoorah-hymn,
rat-a-tat on her bag.

Now glimmergloom goes gloamward still,
and slinkershade sinks deep;
Take cheer: the Creeplegrue lies hushed,
skritch-skritch no more to creep.

poem:
The Wantway and the Wantwight

At gloam the wantway windles broom,
Hush-hush along the sward;
Wantwight sniffs stray-shod bloom tonight,
Shirr-shirr across the sward.

Cinched bramble-brogues and bravecap tight,
Clack-clack my twiggy stave;
Packt lamp, wishnet, wendrite, flint-bright,
for swish of fern I crave.

The desirepath bent from prim-paved,
soft step, a slyish sway;
It hummed with hush-heat, nudgeful whim,
tick-tock of toes astray.

Out loomed Wantwight, whisker-want wide,
hiss-hiss its hunger-yawn;
Thrust thistle-think with thornward stride,
crack-clack—no more its yawn.

Wantway whirred with wishwind, clear-bright,
Hooray along the lane;
Lugged lurebone high, with tremble-cheer,
Ring-rang along the lane.

At gloam the wantway weaves the broom,
Hush-hush upon the sward;
No Wantwight sniffs; strayfeet bloom now—
Whirr-whirr along the sward.

poem:
Mizzlegrim and the Brimmle-Morn Fog

Brimmle-morn, the meadows mum,
hush-hush, shirr-shurr, swoon—
“Beware the Mizzlegrim, my chum,
that hunts when hedges swoon.”

I buckled up my drenchcoat tight,
clink-clank the drizzlebrand—
for mizzle-murk and milkwhite light,
and boots for boggler-sand.

Through thistle-thrum the fog-things flit,
swish-swash, whuff-whirr, hush—
Out loomed the Mizzlegrim, moon-lit,
with teeth like tallow-rush.

We ringed and wrangled round the stile,
skreek-skrak! it swelled the cloud—
I leapt and let the drizzlebrand
bite through its foggy shroud.

Back over bracken-buckle banks,
clip-clap the cobbles rang—
Mist-lint lifted in lapping ranks,
as skylarks sprill-sprung sang.

Brimmle-morn, the meadows hum,
pip-pop, prr-prr, croon—
Be merry, chum; the Mizzlegrim’s done;

poem:
The Third-Rail Trillablare

Mind yon third-rail hum-a-hum,
its zizzing zeal will sting;
the boggle-buzz and bright-bedrum
go brrr and zing-a-zing.

Take up your sparkguard, fold and firm,
dress light in loomproof gear;
and clamp on stormstop soles that firm,
hush, hush the singeing fear.

For out along the tunnel-gloom,
the Voltivyx lies curled;
its crackle-crest and cobalt bloom
hiss-buzzing round the world.

I raised my railwise, rune-laced rod,
ka-clang went track and tie;
we whirrled in whipspark, zinged and trod,
zzap! split its seething cry.

Voltivyx flopped, a flicker-heap,
bzz-bursts went dim and done;
I snared its sparkskull, sunk to sleep,
hum-hush, the battle won.

Back down the burrowed, bronze-bright tracks,
the crowd did clack and cheer;
we clang-sang songs with chuffing sax,
safe hum, not harm, to hear.

Mind yon third-rail hum-a-hum,
now mellow, midnightswing;
the boggle-buzz turns warm-bedrum,
go brmmm—a gentle sing.

poem:
Shutterwhim and the Cinemagritch

In silvermirk the film-ferns swayed,
the safelight hummed—stay slow;
"Beware the Cinemagritch," they said,
"it spools your steps too slow."

I took my timber tripod up,
a leather box for night;
I wound the sprockle-spring—ka-whirr!—
and braced for blinkless fight.

A prime of peering peepish glass,
to pierce the shuttershade;
I slung my strap and flaresome flash—
a quick and quiet blade.

Through fidget-fern and flicker-fog
it slunk where none could see;
The Cinemagritch, spoolbone grin,
went clack-ka-clack—"you see?"

I leveled lens and steady heart,
my flashfang primed with light;
"Snap-SNAP!" the shutter fell—ka-thumm!—
it burned the beast to white.

We washed its wail in washery,
in trays that hush and show;
Fix-fizz went sizzle in the sink,
and stilled its smear to glow.

Back through the lanes of lantern-lilt,
the safelight hummed just so;
In silvermirk I dried my tale,
and film-ferns sway just so.
